message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the headache, such as the excruciating, stabbing pain around one side of the head, tearing of the eye, and occurring in clusters, suggest that the patient has cluster headache. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania and SUNCT syndrome are also types of headache with similar characteristics, but they differ in duration and frequency. Trigeminal neuralgia is also a type of headache, but it is characterized by brief electric shock-like pain in one side of the face.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with excruciating, stabbing pain on the left side of his head and tearing in his left eye, which are typical symptoms of cluster headache. CPH, SUNCT syndrome, and trigeminal neuralgia present with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of excruciating, stabbing pain around the left side of the head, and left-sided tearing indicate cluster headache. The absence of nausea and vomiting also supports this diagnosis. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania also presents with similar symptoms, but it occurs more frequently, and the pain is shorter in duration. Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome presents with similar symptoms but also has additional symptoms like redness in the eye and drooping of the eyelid. Trigeminal neuralgia presents with unilateral facial pain that lasts for seconds to minutes but without tearing as a symptom.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of excruciating, stabbing pain on one side of the head with tearing eye suggests a cluster headache. Other options have different symptoms or duration of pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest cluster headache, which is characterized by intense, stabbing pain on one side of the head, along with tearing of the eyes and nasal congestion. The headache typically lasts for 15 minutes to 3 hours and can happen multiple times throughout the day. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania and short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome are similar conditions but have different patterns and characteristics. Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe facial pain but does not typically involve tearing of the eyes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question point towards a diagnosis of cluster headache. Cluster headaches occur daily or nearly every day and typically last for 30-90 minutes. They are characterized by severe unilateral pain around the eye and temple, sweating, flushing, and nasal congestion. The tearing of the left eye reported by the patient is also a common symptom of cluster headaches. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania (CPH) is similar to cluster headaches but occurs more frequently and for shorter durations. Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome is another type of headache that presents with similar symptoms but is even more severe and lasts for shorter durations. Trigeminal neuralgia typically presents with sudden, severe facial pain that lasts for seconds to several minutes and may recur multiple times a day.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of excruciating, stabbing pain around the left side of the head, and tearing in the left eye occurring for 60 minutes every morning suggest Cluster headache. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania (CPH) and Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome have similar symptoms, but CPH lasts for a shorter duration and SUNCT has shorter attacks with a higher frequency. Trigeminal neuralgia typically has shorter attacks with a higher frequency and is triggered by specific activities or triggers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation of stabbing pain, tearing of the left eye, and occurring in clusters all suggest cluster headache. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania can also present with similar symptoms, but it is a continuous headache with intermittent severe pain. Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome presents with similar symptoms, but the duration of the headaches is usually shorter. Trigeminal neuralgia presents with brief episodes of severe pain in the face, typically provoked by sensory stimuli.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of excruciating, stabbing pain around the left side of his head, with tearing in one eye and occurring every morning for the past week, are consistent with cluster headache. The other options have slightly different symptoms or durations of headache attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms mentioned in the question are characteristic of cluster headaches, including excruciating, stabbing pain, tearing, and occurring daily at a specific time. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania and SUNCT may have similar symptoms, but they typically last for a shorter duration. Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, sharp facial pain and is not likely to present with tearing of the eye.
